info.title: Ocean - Commercial Schedules [DCSA]
info.description: Retrieve vessel schedules, cargo routings and port schedules based on the Commercial Schedules standard by the [Digital Container Shipping Association](https://dcsa.org/standards/commercial-schedules/) # Overview Streamline your logistics processes with the DCSA-compliant Commercial Schedules API based on the **DCSA Interface standard v.1.0.1**. This API simplifies integration, reduces manual steps, and ensures consistent data across carriers and platforms. # Why use it? The DCSA Commercial Schedules (CS) standard creates a common way for carriers to communicate vessel schedule information to customers. With the DCSA CS standard in place, customers can expect to receive high-quality data about their container shipments regardless of which carrier is transporting them. CS provides three options for accessing schedules from carriers: - **Point- to-Point Routing**: provides single or multiple end-to-end routing options with estimated timestamps during the pre-booking phase; - **Port Schedule**: provides estimated timestamps for all vessels arriving and departing from a defined port/terminal on a given date; - **Vessel Schedules**: provides estimated departure and arrival times for a required service, voyage or vessel, for each port call on the vessel’s rotation. # Deprecation of legacy Schedule APIs With the release of the **DCSA Commercial Schedules API**, we are beginning the retirement of two legacy APIs. The following APIs are **deprecated** and scheduled for decommissioning: - **Vessel Schedules** - **Point-to-Point Schedules** The legacy **Vessel Schedules** and **Point-to-Point Schedules** APIs will remain available until **September 1, 2026**.\ After this date, both APIs will be **permanently decommissioned** and no longer supported.\ We recommend migrating to the new API as early as possible to avoid service disruption. For migration guidance, please **contact our support team**. # Who can get access? All registered users of the Maersk Developer Portal can get access to the API. # Getting started Access to this API is limited to approved developers currently doing business with Maersk. To request access, you need to **login** using your company email address and create an Integration to enable this API product for your Consumer Key. For step-by-step instructions, please refer to our **Getting Started Guide**. # How many calls can I make? Traffic and spike arrest limits are configured at the consumer key level for each API Product as detailed in the table below. If these limits are exceeded, the request is rejected with a 429 Too Many Requests HTTP status code. | Quota per Consumer Key | Traffic Surge Rate Limit per Consumer Key | |------------------------|-------------------------------------------| | 1,000 calls per hour | 60 calls per minute | # Release Notes | Version | Date | Notes | |---------|------|-------| | 1.0.1 | 2025-09-05 | the first release | # FAQs (Frequently Asked Questions) **Q: What is the difference between the DCSA Commercial Schedules API and the existing Vessel Schedules API?**\ A: The DCSA Commercial Schedules API includes three endpoints. Among them, the `/vessel-schedules` and `port-schedules` endpoints are enhanced versions of the existing Vessel Schedules API, offering additional features and improved functionality. Key enhancements include: - Adoption of the DCSA standard data model - Support for industry-standard codes (e.g., UN/LOCODE, SMDG facility codes, vessel IMO numbers) - Support schedules by service - The data structure has been redesigned in the DCSA version to organize schedules by service instead of by vessel - Inclusion of UTC timezone offsets for departureDate and arrivalDate - Support for `PLN`, `EST` and `ACT` event classifier codes - Full voyage coverage - Flexible schedules query options using: UNLocationCode, facilitySMDGCode, vesselOperatorCarrierCode, carrierServiceCode, carrierVoyageNumber, and any of these combinations - Pagination support for efficient data handling **Q: What is the difference between the DCSA Commercial Schedules API and the existing Point-to-Point Schedules API?**\ A: The DCSA Commercial Schedules API includes three endpoints. The `/point-to-point-routes` endpoint is an enhanced version of the existing Point-to-Point Schedules API, offering additional features and improved functionality. Key enhancements include: - Adoption of the DCSA standard data model - Support for industry-standard codes (e.g., UN/LOCODE, SMDG facility codes, vessel IMO numbers) - Inclusion of UTC timezone offsets for departureDate and arrivalDate - Ability to filter routings by the maximum number of transhipments using the new `maxTranshipment` query parameter - Introduction of `routingReference` to associate routings with bookings (new feature coming in 2026 with the **DCSA Booking API v2**) **Q: Does the API support pagination?**\ A: Yes, pagination is supported on the `/vessel-schedules` and `/port-schedules` endpoints. However, the `/point-to-point-routes` endpoint does not support pagination due to backend system restrictions. **Q: Does the API provide cutOffTimes or deadlines?**\ A: Not currently. Support for cut-off times is planned and included in our product backlog for Q4 2025. **Q: Does the `/point-to-to-routes` endpoint support Named Account routes?**\ A: Not currently. However, support for Named Account routes is on our product roadmap for 2026.
info.x-release-notes:
# Version     Date     Notes
# 1.0.1    2025-06-31  the first release

get.description:
Provides the product offering of single or multiple estimated end-to-end route options for a shipment in the pre-booking phase. This includes point-to-point specification of all transport legs, estimated timings, estimated schedules and interdependencies between transport legs.

The list of solutions returned in the response can be tailored to a specific need by combining available query parameters.

The minimum required query parameters are `placeOfReceipt` and `placeOfDelivery`. If no further query parameters are used to tailor the response, the provider of the GET endpoint will return their best suggestions in the response. 

The `GET /v1/point-to-point-routes` endpoint can be implemented independently of having implemented the `GET /v1/port-schedules`  and `GET /v1/vessel-schedules`  endpoints.

**Maersk remark**: this endpoint does not support pagination, the routes matched to the query will be returned in one page

parameters.name: placeOfReceipt
parameters.description: The `UNLocationCode` specifying where the place is located.

parameters.name: placeOfDelivery
parameters.description: The `UNLocationCode` specifying where the place is located.

parameters.name: departureStartDate
parameters.description:
Limit the result based on the earliest departureDate.

- If provided without departureEndDate, returns all routings with
departures from the specified departureStartDate onwards.

- If provided with departureEndDate, returns all routings with
departures within the specified date range, inclusive of both dates.

- If the same date is provided for both departureStartDate and
departureEndDate, returns all routings with departures on that
specific date.

**Maersk remark**:
- the default date range is 4 weeks ( 28 days ) if only departureStartDate or departureEndDate is provided
- the default departureStartDate is tomorrow if departureDate and arrivalDate are not provided
- the maximum date range between departureStartDate and departureEndDate is 8 weeks ( 56 days )

parameters.name: departureEndDate
parameters.description:
Limit the result based on the latest departureDate. 

- If provided without departureStartDate, returns all routings with
departures up to the specified departureEndDate.

- If provided with departureStartDate, returns all routings with
departures within the specified date range, inclusive of both dates.

- If the same date is provided for both departureStartDate and
departureEndDate, returns all routings with departures on that
specific date.

**Maersk remark**:
- the default date range is 4 weeks ( 28 days ) if only departureStartDate or departureEndDate is provided
- the maximum date range between departureStartDate and departureEndDate is 8 weeks ( 56 days )

parameters.name: arrivalStartDate
parameters.description:
Limit the result based on the earliest arrivalDate.

- If provided without arrivalEndDate, returns all routings with
arrivals from the specified arrivalStartDate.

- If provided with arrivalEndDate, returns all routings with
arrivals within the specified date range, inclusive of both dates.

- If the same date is provided for both arrivalStartDate and
arrivalEndDate, returns all routings with arrivals on that specific
date.

**Maersk remark**:
- the default date range is 4 weeks ( 28 days ) if only arrivalStartDate or arrivalEndDate is provided
- the maximum date range between arrivalStartDate and arrivalEndDate is 8 weeks ( 56 days )

parameters.name: arrivalEndDate
parameters.description:
Limit the result based on the latest arrivalDate.

- If provided without arrivalStartDate, returns all routings with
arrivals up to the specified arrivalEndDate.

- If provided with arrivalStartDate, returns all routings with
arrivals within the specified date range, inclusive of both dates.

- If the same date is provided for both arrivalStartDate and
arrivalEndDate, returns all routings with arrivals on that specific
date.

**Maersk remark**:
- the default date range is 4 weeks ( 28 days ) if only arrivalStartDate or arrivalEndDate is provided
- the maximum date range between arrivalStartDate and arrivalEndDate is 8 weeks ( 56 days )

parameters.name: maxTranshipment
parameters.description:
Specifies the maximum number of transhipments that the proposed routings can have in the response. By default, transhipments are allowed and the responses can have either direct routings or routings with transhipment. The default value of maximum transhipments is defined by the carrier for when the consumer does not provide a value. If the user sets the number of transhipments to 0, only direct routings can be returned in the response.
**Note:** According to the DCSA definition, a “transhipment” specifically refers to transferring containers or cargo from one vessel to another, focusing exclusively on ocean transport. This means that, under the current interpretation, only vessel-to-vessel transfers are counted as transhipments. Moves between road, rail, or barge and a vessel (i.e., inland legs) do not fall under this definition and, therefore, should not be counted as transhipments.

parameters.name: receiptTypeAtOrigin
parameters.description:
Indicates the type of service offered at Origin. **Carriers can choose to define a default value when the consumer does not provide it.**
  - `CY` (Container yard (incl. rail ramp))  
  - `SD` (Store Door)  
  - `CFS` (Container Freight Station)
  
Maersk remark: defalut value is `CY`

parameters.name: deliveryTypeAtDestination
parameters.description:
Indicates the type of service offered at Destination. **Carriers can choose to define a default value when the consumer does not provide it.**
  - `CY` (Container yard (incl. rail ramp))  
  - `SD` (Store Door)  
  - `CFS` (Container Freight Station)
  
Maersk remark: defalut value is `CY`

parameters.name: API-Version
parameters.description: An API-Version header **MAY** be added to the request (optional); if added it **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version. API-Version header **MUST** be aligned with the URI version.

API-Version.description: SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned
SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.
SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.

get.description:
Provides, for a required specific port and starting date, the set of all vessels arriving and departing from the port with the corresponding estimated timestamps.

The port must be identified by its UN Location Code. 

The required query parameters are `UNLocationCode` and `date`. 

If the requested port (identified with `UNLocationCode`) has multiple terminals (identified with `facilitySMDGCode`), the response will include a sorted list that provides all the arrivals and departures of the vessels for each terminal of the port (`UNLocationCode`). 

The `GET /v1/port-schedules` endpoint can be implemented independently of having implemented the  `GET /v1/point-to-point-routes`  and `GET /v1/vessel-schedules`  endpoints.

parameters.name: UNLocationCode
parameters.description: The UN Location code specifying where the place is located. Specifying this filter will only return the set of all vessels arriving and departing from the port and its terminals.

parameters.name: date
parameters.description:
The date since when the estimated arrival and departures of vessels in a given port is required.

\
**Maersk remark**: The allowed date is 90 days before the current date and 180 days after the current date. The API will return the matched schedules within this date range.

parameters.name: API-Version
parameters.description: An API-Version header **MAY** be added to the request (optional); if added it **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version. API-Version header **MUST** be aligned with the URI version.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Specifies the maximum number of `Port Schedule` objects to return.

\
**Maersk remark**: the default and maximum limit is 10

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: A server generated value to specify a specific point in a collection result, used for pagination.

API-Version.description: SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.

Next-Page-Cursor.description:
The Next-Page-Cursor header contains a cursor value that points to the next page of results in a paginated API response.
When an initial `GET` endpoint request includes the query parameter `limit=...` the API provider limits the number of items in the root array of the response to the specified limit. If the response would contain more items than the specified limit, the API provider includes only the first set of limit items and appends the following response header:
`Next-Page-Cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA`, a string that acts as a reference for the next page of results. The cursor value is used in subsequent requests to retrieve the next page by passing it as a query parameter: `?cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA`.

To retrieve the next page, the API consumer sends a `GET` request to the endpoint URL with only `?cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA` as query parameter. The limit of items per page and any other query parameters may not be altered, therefore it may also not be specified when requesting subsequent pages. The API provider must ignore any query parameters passed along with a cursor, and should return a `400` error if any other query parameter is passed along with the `cursor`.

API-Version.description: SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.
SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.

get.description:
Provides, for a required specific service and/or voyage and/or vessel and/or location, the timetable of estimated departure and arrival times for each port call on the rotation of the vessel(s).

The list of schedules returned in the response can be tailored to specific needs by combining available query parameters. 

A filter parameter or a combination of filter parameters MUST always be provided to call the endpoint. Examples of typical query parameters and expected payload returned in the response:

- a) `carrierServiceCode`: Get all vessels and their full voyages within a service   

- b) `carrierServiceCode` **&** `carrierVoyageNumber`: Get a specific full voyage within a service

- c) `carrierServiceCode` **&** `vesselIMONumber`: Get a specific vessel’s full voyages within a service. 

- d) `vesselIMONumber`: Get all full voyages for a specific vessel across all the services in which it is involved.

- e) `UNLocationCode`: Get all vessels and their full voyages where the specific `UNLocationCode` is involved

- f) `UNLocationCode` **&** `facilitySMDGCode`: Get all vessels and their full voyages where the specific  `UNLocationCode` and `facilitySMDGCode` is involved

Other combinations using `vesselName`, `universalServiceReference`, `universalVoyageReference`, `vesselOperatorCarrierCode`, `startDate`, `endDate` are possible. 

The filter parameters `startDate` and `endDate` MUST always be used in combination with any of the other available parameters.

The resulting payload returned in the responses will always include **entire voyage(s) being matched**. This means that even though a filter only matches a single `Port` (`UNLocationCode`) in a `Voyage` or a single `Timestamp` within a `Port` in a `Voyage` - **the entire Voyage matched** is returned. If the `carrierImportVoyageNumber` of the `Port` differs from the `carrierExportVoyageNumber` of the `Port` then the **entire Voyage** for both these Voyage numbers are included. An example of this is when `&UNLocationCode=DEHAM` is used as a filter parameter. In this case **entire Voyages** would be listed where `DEHAM` is a `Port`.

Be aware that it is possible to specify filters that are mutually exclusive resulting in an empty response list. An example of this could be when both using `vesselIMONumber` and `vesselName` filters at the same time: `&vesselIMONumber=9321483&vesselName=King of the Seas`. If no `Vessel` exists where `vesselIMONumber` is **9321483** and `vesselName` is **King of the Seas** then the result will be an empty list. 

If no `startDate` filter is provided, then **3 months** before the request date should be used as default. If no `endDate` filter is provided, then **6 months** after the request date should be used as default. The endpoint provider can customize these based on their business definitions and inform the consumers what to expect in a response when these filters are not used. 

The `GET /v1/vessel-schedules` endpoint can be implemented independently of having implemented the  `GET /v1/point-to-point-routes`  and `GET /v1/port-schedules`  endpoints. 

**IMPORTANT**: This endpoint is for carriers to make available vessel schedules to BCO, LSP, and Solution Platforms, with a commercial purpose; this is out of the boundaries of their vessel schedules alignment with other carriers and terminals for operational purposes for which the Operational Vessel Schedules [API](https://app.swaggerhub.com/apis/dcsaorg/DCSA_OVS/3.0.0) is used between carriers, and carriers and terminals.

parameters.name: vesselIMONumber
parameters.description: The unique reference for a registered Vessel. The reference is the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) number, also sometimes known as the Lloyd's register code, which does not change during the lifetime of the vessel.

parameters.name: vesselName
parameters.description: The name of a vessel. The result will only return schedules including the vessel with the specified name.  Be aware that the vesselName is not unique and might match multiple vessels.

parameters.name: carrierServiceCode
parameters.description: The carrier specific service code to filter by. The result will only return schedules including the service code.

parameters.name: universalServiceReference
parameters.description:
The Universal Service Reference (USR) as defined by DCSA to filter by.

\
**Maersk remark**: not supported in this API version

parameters.name: carrierVoyageNumber
parameters.description: The carrier specific identifier of a Voyage - can be both `importVoyageNumber` and `exportVoyageNumber`. The result will only return schedules including the Ports where `carrierVoyageNumber` is either `carrierImportVoyageNumber` or `carrierExportVoyageNumber`.

parameters.name: universalVoyageReference
parameters.description:
The Universal Reference of a Voyage - can be both `importUniversalVoyageReference` and `exportUniversalVoyageReference`. The result will only return schedules including the Ports where `universalVoyageReference` is either `importUniversalVoyageReference` or `exportUniversalVoyageReference`.

\
**Maersk remark**: not supported in this API version

parameters.name: UNLocationCode
parameters.description:
The UN Location Code specifying where a port is located.  Specifying
this filter will only return schedules including entire Voyages
related to this particular UN Location Code.

\
**Maersk remark**: `UNLocationCode` is mandatory when `facilitySMDGCode` is used

parameters.name: facilitySMDGCode
parameters.description: The facilitySMDGCode specifying a specific facility (using SMDG Code). Be aware that the `facilitySMDGCode` does not contain a `UNLocationCode` - this must be specified in the `UNLocationCode` filter.  Specifying this filter will only return schedules including entire Voyages related to this particular `facilitySMDGCode`. It is recommended to specify a value for this query parameter only if a value is provided for `UNLocationCode`.

parameters.name: vesselOperatorCarrierCode
parameters.description:
The carrier who is in charge of the vessel operation based on either the SMDG or SCAC code lists.

\
**Maersk remark**: the API only support SMDG carrier code e.g "MSK"

parameters.name: startDate
parameters.description:
The start date of the period for which schedule information is requested. If a date of any Timestamp (ATA, ETA or PTA) inside a PortCall matches a date on or after (≥) the `startDate` the entire Voyage (import- and export-Voyage) matching the PortCall will be included in the result. All matching is done towards local Date at the place of the port call.
If this filter is not provided, the default value is **3 months** prior to the request time.

\
**Maersk remark**: The allowed startDate is 90 days before the current date and 180 days after the current date. If not provided, the current date is used by default.

parameters.name: endDate
parameters.description:
The end date of the period for which schedule information is requested. If a date of any Timestamp (ATA, ETA or PTA) inside a PortCall matches a date on or before (≤) the `endDate` the entire Voyage(import- and export-Voyage) matching the PortCall will be included in the result. All matching is done towards local Date at the place of the port call.  

\
**Maersk remark**: The allowed endDate is 90 days before the current date and 180 days after the current date. If not provided, the `startDate` + 28 days is used by default.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
Specifies the maximum number of `Service Schedule` objects to return.

\
**Maersk remark**: the default and maximum limit is 3

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description: A server generated value to specify a specific point in a collection result, used for pagination.

parameters.name: API-Version
parameters.description: An API-Version header **MAY** be added to the request (optional); if added it **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version. API-Version header **MUST** be aligned with the URI version.

API-Version.description: SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.

Next-Page-Cursor.description:
The Next-Page-Cursor header contains a cursor value that points to the next page of results in a paginated API response.
When an initial `GET` endpoint request includes the query parameter `limit=...` the API provider limits the number of items in the root array of the response to the specified limit. If the response would contain more items than the specified limit, the API provider includes only the first set of limit items and appends the following response header:
`Next-Page-Cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA`, a string that acts as a reference for the next page of results. The cursor value is used in subsequent requests to retrieve the next page by passing it as a query parameter: `?cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA`.

To retrieve the next page, the API consumer sends a `GET` request to the endpoint URL with only `?cursor=fE9mZnNldHw9MTAmbGltaXQ9MTA` as query parameter. The limit of items per page and any other query parameters may not be altered, therefore it may also not be specified when requesting subsequent pages. The API provider must ignore any query parameters passed along with a cursor, and should return a `400` error if any other query parameter is passed along with the `cursor`.

API-Version.description: SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.
SemVer used to indicate the version of the contract (API version) returned.

PlaceOfReceipt.title: Place of Receipt

facilityTypeCode.description:
The code to identify the specific type of facility. The code indicates which role the facility plays during the transportCall.
- `BORD` (Border)
- `CLOC` (Customer Location)
- `COFS` (Container Freight Station)
- `OFFD` (Off Dock Storage)
- `DEPO` (Depot)
- `INTE` (Inland Terminal)
- `POTE` (Port Terminal)
- `PBPL` (Pilot Boarding Place)
- `BRTH` (Berth)
- `RAMP` (Ramp)
- `WAYP` (Waypoint)

dateTime.description: The local date and time, when the event will take place.

PlaceOfReceipt.description: The Location specifying where the place of receipt is located.

PlaceOfDelivery.title: Place of Delivery

facilityTypeCode.description:
The code to identify the specific type of facility. The code indicates which role the facility plays during the transportCall.
- `BORD` (Border)
- `CLOC` (Customer Location)
- `COFS` (Container Freight Station)
- `OFFD` (Off Dock Storage)
- `DEPO` (Depot)
- `INTE` (Inland Terminal)
- `POTE` (Port Terminal)
- `PBPL` (Pilot Boarding Place)
- `BRTH` (Berth)
- `RAMP` (Ramp)
- `WAYP` (Waypoint)

dateTime.description: The local date and time, when the event will take place.

PlaceOfDelivery.description: The Location specifying where the place of delivery is located.

PlaceOfArrival.title: Place of Arrival

facilityTypeCode.description:
The code to identify the specific type of facility. The code indicates which role the facility plays during the transportCall.
- `BORD` (Border)
- `CLOC` (Customer Location)
- `COFS` (Container Freight Station)
- `OFFD` (Off Dock Storage)
- `DEPO` (Depot)
- `INTE` (Inland Terminal)
- `POTE` (Port Terminal)
- `PBPL` (Pilot Boarding Place)
- `BRTH` (Berth)
- `RAMP` (Ramp)
- `WAYP` (Waypoint)

dateTime.description: The local date and time, when the event will take place.

PlaceOfArrival.description: The Location specifying where the place of arrival is located.

PlaceOfDeparture.title: Place of Departure

facilityTypeCode.description:
The code to identify the specific type of facility. The code indicates which role the facility plays during the transportCall.
- `BORD` (Border)
- `CLOC` (Customer Location)
- `COFS` (Container Freight Station)
- `OFFD` (Off Dock Storage)
- `DEPO` (Depot)
- `INTE` (Inland Terminal)
- `POTE` (Port Terminal)
- `PBPL` (Pilot Boarding Place)
- `BRTH` (Berth)
- `RAMP` (Ramp)
- `WAYP` (Waypoint)

dateTime.description: The local date and time, when the event will take place.

PlaceOfDeparture.description: The Location specifying where the place of departure is located.

receiptTypeAtOrigin.description:
Indicates the type of service offered at `Origin`. The options are:
- `CY` (Container yard (incl. rail ramp))
- `SD` (Store Door)
- `CFS` (Container Freight Station)

deliveryTypeAtDestination.description:
Indicates the type of service offered at `Destination`. The options are:
- `CY` (Container yard (incl. rail ramp))
- `SD` (Store Door)
- `CFS` (Container Freight Station)

cutOffTimes.description: A list of cut-offs times provided by the carrier when available. A cut-off time indicates the latest date and time by which a task must be completed. For example, the latest date and time by which a container must be delivered to a terminal to be loaded on a vessel, or where certain documentation must be provided by the Shipper.

solutionNumber.description:
Solution number, starting with 1. Used to group and identify similar or same routings in the response as per the carrier commercial definitions.

\
**Maersk remark**: the solution number is a random internal number for grouping

routingReference.description: A reference to be used when creating a **Booking** in the **Booking API**.

transitTime.description: The estimated total time in days that it takes a shipment to move from place of receipt to place of delivery. Transit time includes stop-over time during transhipments and waiting time at connection points, if applicable, thus can vary between the same locations.

universalServiceReference.description: A global unique service reference, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the service. The service reference must match the regular expression pattern: `SR\d{5}[A-Z]`. The letters `SR` followed by `5` digits, followed by a checksum-character as a capital letter from `A to Z`.

isDummyVessel.description: This property can be set to `true` when no vessel has been assigned, indicating that the `vesselIMONumber` does not exist.

universalImportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the import Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

universalExportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the export Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

cutOffTimes.description: A list of cut-offs times provided by the carrier when available. A cut-off time indicates the latest date and time by which a task must be completed. For example, the latest date and time by which a container must be delivered to a terminal to be loaded on a vessel, or where certain documentation must be provided by the Shipper.

portVisitReference.description: The unique reference that can be used to link different `transportCallReferences` to the same port visit. The reference is provided by the port to uniquely identify a port call.

transportCallReference.description: The unique reference for a transport call. It’s the vessel operator’s responsibility to provide the Transport Call Reference, other parties are obliged to pick it up and use it. It can take the form of Port Call References as defined in OVS Definitions Document, or alternatively a reference as defined by the vessel operator.

carrierImportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an import voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the import Voyage.

carrierExportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an export voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the export Voyage.

universalImportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the import Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

universalExportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the export Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

cutOffTimes.description: A list of cut-offs times provided by the carrier when available. A cut-off time indicates the latest date and time by which a task must be completed. For example, the latest date and time by which a container must be delivered to a terminal to be loaded on a vessel, or where certain documentation must be provided by the Shipper.

eventClassifierCode.description:
Code for the event classifier. Values can vary depending on eventType.

Possible values are:
- `ACT` (Actual)
- `EST` (Estimated)
- `PLN` (Planned)

eventDateTime.description: The local date and time, when the event takes place.

carrierServiceCode.description: The carrier-specific code of the service for which the schedule details are published.

universalServiceReference.description: A global unique service reference, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the service.

isDummyVessel.description: This property can be set to `true` when no vessel has been assigned, indicating that the `vesselIMONumber` does not exist.

cutOffDateTimeCode.description:
Code for the cut-off time. Possible values are:
  - `DCO` (Documentation cut-off)
  - `VCO` (VGM cut-off)
  - `FCO` (FCL delivery cut-off)
  - `LCO` (LCL delivery cut-off) **Condition:** only when the `Receipt Type at Origin` is `CFS`
  - `PCO` (Port cut-off)
  - `ECP` (Empty container pick-up date and time)
  - `EFC` (Earliest full-container delivery date)
  - `RCO` (Reefer cut-off)
  - `DGC` (Dangerous Goods cut-off)
  - `OBC` (OOG/BB cut-off)
  - `TCO` (Transhipment cut-off)
  - `STA` (Standard booking acceptance)
  - `SPA` (Special booking acceptance)
  - `CUA` (Customs Acceptance)
  - `AFC` (Advanced filling cut-off)

cutOffDateTime.description: Estimated cut-off time expressed in local time with offset.

Address.title: Address

floor.description: The floor of the street number.

countryCode.description: The 2 characters for the country code using [ISO 3166-1 alpha-2](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:pub:PUB500001:en)

Address.description: An object for storing address related information.

httpMethod.description: The HTTP method used to make the request e.g. `GET`, `POST`, etc

statusCodeText.description: A standard short description corresponding to the HTTP status code.

statusCodeMessage.description: A long description corresponding to the HTTP status code with additional information.
statusCodeMessage.example: The supplied data could not be accepted

providerCorrelationReference.description: A unique identifier to the HTTP request within the scope of the API provider.

errorDateTime.description: The DateTime corresponding to the error occurring.

errors.description: An array of errors providing more detail about the root cause.

vesselIMONumber.description: The unique reference for a registered Vessel. The reference is the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) number, also sometimes known as the Lloyd's register code, which does not change during the lifetime of the vessel.

MMSINumber.description: Maritime Mobile Service Identities (MMSIs) are nine-digit numbers used by maritime digital selective calling (DSC), automatic identification systems (AIS) and certain other equipment to uniquely identify a ship or a coast radio station.

name.description: The name of the Vessel given by the Vessel Operator and registered with IMO.

flag.description: The flag of the nation whose laws the vessel is registered under. This is the [ISO 3166](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:pub:PUB500001:en) two-letter country code.

callSign.description: A unique alphanumeric identity that belongs to the vessel and is assigned by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). It consists of a three letter alphanumeric prefix that indicates nationality, followed by one to four characters to identify the individual vessel. For instance, vessels registered under Denmark are assigned the prefix ranges 5PA-5QZ, OUAOZZ, and XPA-XPZ. The Call Sign changes whenever a vessel changes its flag.

operatorCarrierCode.description: The carrier who is in charge of the vessel operation based on either the SMDG or SCAC code lists.

operatorCarrierCodeListProvider.description:
Identifies the code list provider used for the operator and partner carriercodes.
- `SMDG` (Ship Message Design Group)
- `NMFTA` (National Motor Freight Traffic Association)

vesselIMONumber.description: The unique reference for a registered Vessel. The reference is the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) number, also sometimes known as the Lloyd's register code, which does not change during the lifetime of the vessel.

MMSINumber.description: Maritime Mobile Service Identities (MMSIs) are nine-digit numbers used by maritime digital selective calling (DSC), automatic identification systems (AIS) and certain other equipment to uniquely identify a ship or a coast radio station.

name.description: The name of the Vessel given by the Vessel Operator and registered with IMO.

flag.description: The flag of the nation whose laws the vessel is registered under. This is the ISO 3166 two-letter country code.

callSign.description: A unique alphanumeric identity that belongs to the vessel and is assigned by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). It consists of a three letter alphanumeric prefix that indicates nationality, followed by one to four characters to identify the individual vessel. For instance, vessels registered under Denmark are assigned the prefix ranges 5PA-5QZ, OUAOZZ, and XPA-XPZ. The Call Sign changes whenever a vessel changes its flag.

operatorCarrierCode.description: The carrier who is in charge of the vessel operation based on either the SMDG or SCAC code lists.

operatorCarrierCodeListProvider.description:
Identifies the code list provider used for the operator and partner carriercodes.
- `SMDG` (Ship Message Design Group)
- `NMFTA` (National Motor Freight Traffic Association)

modeOfTransport.description: The mode of transport as defined by DCSA. For the Vessel Transport mode this needs to be `VESSEL`.

portVisitReference.description: The unique reference that can be used to link different `transportCallReferences` to the same port visit. The reference is provided by the port to uniquely identify a port call.

transportCallReference.description: The unique reference for a transport call. It’s the vessel operator’s responsibility to provide the Transport Call Reference, other parties are obliged to pick it up and use it. It can take the form of Port Call References as defined in OVS Definitions Document, or alternatively a reference as defined by the vessel operator.

universalServiceReference.description: A global unique service reference, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the service. The service reference must match the regular expression pattern: `SR\d{5}[A-Z]`. The letters `SR` followed by `5` digits, followed by a checksum-character as a capital letter from `A to Z`.

universalExportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the export Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage. The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

universalImportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the import Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage. The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

modeOfTransport.description: The mode of transport as defined by DCSA. For the Barge Transport mode this needs to be `BARGE`.

portVisitReference.description: The unique reference that can be used to link different `transportCallReferences` to the same port visit. The reference is provided by the port to uniquely identify a port call.

transportCallReference.description: The unique reference for a transport call. It’s the vessel operator’s responsibility to provide the Transport Call Reference, other parties are obliged to pick it up and use it. It can take the form of Port Call References as defined in OVS Definitions Document, or alternatively a reference as defined by the vessel operator.

universalServiceReference.description: A global unique service reference, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the service. The service reference must match the regular expression pattern: `SR\d{5}[A-Z]`. The letters `SR` followed by `5` digits, followed by a checksum-character as a capital letter from `A to Z`.

universalExportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the export Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

universalImportVoyageReference.description:
A global unique voyage reference for the import Voyage, as per DCSA standard, agreed by VSA partners for the voyage.The voyage reference must match the regular expression pattern: `\d{2}[0-9A-Z]{2}[NEWSR]`

- `2 digits` for the year
- `2 alphanumeric characters` for the sequence number of the voyage
- `1 character` for the direction/haul (`N`orth, `E`ast, `W`est, `S`outh or `R`oundtrip).

modeOfTransport.description:
The mode of transport as defined by DCSA. The allowed values for the Other Transport mode are:
- `RAIL` (When the transport mode is Rail)
- `TRUCK`(When the transport mode is Truck)
- `RAIL_TRUCK`(When rail and truck are expected to be the mode of transport in a leg of a proposed routing)
- `BARGE_TRUCK`(When barge and truck are expected to be the mode of transport in a leg of a proposed routing)
- `BARGE_RAIL`(When barge and rail are expected to be the mode of transport in a leg of a proposed routing)
- `MULTIMODAL`(When mode of transport is not really defined or unknown at this stage)

Facility.title: Facility

facilityCode.description:
The code used for identifying the specific facility. This code does not include the UN Location Code.The definition of the code depends on the `facilityCodeListProvider`. As code list providers maintain multiple codeLists the following codeList is used:
  - for `SMDG` - the codeList used is the [SMDG Terminal Code List](https://smdg.org/documents/smdg-code-lists/)
  - for `BIC`  - the codeList used is the [BIC Facility Codes](https://www.bic-code.org/facility-codes/)

facilityCodeListProvider.description:
The provider used for identifying the facility Code. Some facility codes are only defined in combination with an `UN Location Code`.
- `BIC` (Requires a UN Location Code) 
- `SMDG` (Requires a UN Location Code)

Facility.description: A way to express a location using a `Facility`. The facility can either be expressed using a `BIC` code or a `SMDG` code. The `facilityCode` does not contain the `UNLocationCode` - this should be provided in the `UnLocationCode` attribute.

ServicePartner.title: Service Partner

carrierCode.description: The carrier code based on either the SMDG or SCAC code lists.

carrierCodeListProvider.description:
Identifies the code list provider used for the `carrierCode`.
- `SMDG` (Ship Message Design Group)
- `NMFTA` (National Motor Freight Traffic Association)

carrierServiceCode.description: The carrier-specific code of the service for which the schedule details are published.

carrierImportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an import voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the import Voyage.

carrierExportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an export voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the export Voyage.

ServicePartner.description: The service code and voyage number as identified by the carriers that are partners in the service.

ServicePartnerSchedule.title: Service Partner Schedule

carrierCode.description: The carrier code based on either the SMDG or SCAC code lists.

carrierCodeListProvider.description:
Identifies the code list provider used for the `carrierCode`.
- `SMDG` (Ship Message Design Group)
- `NMFTA` (National Motor Freight Traffic Association)

carrierServiceCode.description: The carrier-specific code of the service for which the schedule details are published.

carrierImportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an import voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the import Voyage.

carrierExportVoyageNumber.description: The identifier of an export voyage. The carrier-specific identifier of the export Voyage.

ServicePartnerSchedule.description: The service code and voyage number as identified by the carriers that are partners in the service.

Leg.title: Leg

transport.description: The mode of transport as defined by DCSA.

Leg.description: Leg of the Point-to-Point routing. The property `Leg` can be conformed by as many leg as needed and this leg must be identified with a sequence number.

Location.title: Location

locationName.description: An optional name for the location.

UNLocationCode.description:
The UN Location code specifying where the place is located. The pattern used must be

- 2 characters for the country code using [ISO 3166-1 alpha-2](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:pub:PUB500001:en)
- 3 characters to code a location within that country. Letters A-Z and numbers from 2-9 can be used

More info can be found here: [UN/LOCODE](https://unece.org/trade/cefact/UNLOCODE-Download)

Location.description:
The location can be specified using **any** of the nested structures:
  - `Address` (used to specify the location via an Address)
  - `UNLocationCode`
  - `Facility` (used to specify a location using a `facilityCode` and a `facilityCodeListProvider`)

  It is expected that if a location is specified in multiple ways (both as an `Address` and as a `Facility`) that both ways point to the same location.

TransportCallLocation.title: TransportCall Location

locationName.description: An optional name for the location.

UNLocationCode.description:
The UN Location code specifying where the place is located. The pattern used must be

  - 2 characters for the country code using [ISO 3166-1 alpha-2](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:pub:PUB500001:en)
  - 3 characters to code a location within that country. Letters A-Z and numbers from 2-9 can be used

  More info can be found here: [UN/LOCODE](https://unece.org/trade/cefact/UNLOCODE-Download)

facilitySMDGCode.description:
The code used for identifying the specific facility. This code does not include the UN Location Code.
The codeList used by SMDG is the [SMDG Terminal Code List](https://smdg.org/documents/smdg-code-lists/)

TransportCallLocation.description:
General purpose object to capture location-related data, the location can be specified in **any** of the following ways:
  - `Address` (used to specify the location via an Address)
  - `UNLocationCode`
  - `FacilitySMDGCode` (used to specify a location using a `facilitySMDGCode`)
  It is expected that if a location is specified in multiple ways (both as an `Address` and as a `Facility`) that both ways point to the same location.

PortScheduleLocation.title: Port Schedule Location

locationName.description: An optional name for the location.

UNLocationCode.description:
The UN Location code specifying where the place is located. The pattern used must be

  - 2 characters for the country code using [ISO 3166-1 alpha-2](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:pub:PUB500001:en)
  - 3 characters to code a location within that country. Letters A-Z and numbers from 2-9 can be used

  More info can be found here: [UN/LOCODE](https://unece.org/trade/cefact/UNLOCODE-Download)

facilitySMDGCode.description:
The code used for identifying the specific facility. This code does not include the UN Location Code.
The codeList used by SMDG is the [SMDG Terminal Code List](https://smdg.org/documents/smdg-code-lists/)

PortScheduleLocation.description:
General purpose object to capture location-related data, the location can be specified in **any** of the following ways:
  - `UNLocationCode`
  - `FacilitySMDGCode` (used to specify a location using a `facilitySMDGCode`)

  It is expected that if a location is specified in multiple ways (both as a `UNLocationCode` and as a `facilitySMDGCode`) that both ways point to the same location.

DetailedError.title: Detailed Error

errorCode.description:
The detailed error code returned.

  - `7000-7999` Technical error codes
  - `8000-8999` Functional error codes
  - `9000-9999` API provider-specific error codes            

[Error codes as specified by DCSA](https://developer.dcsa.org/standard-error-codes).

property.description: The name of the property causing the error.

value.description: The value of the property causing the error serialised as a string exactly as in the original request.

jsonPath.description: A path to the property causing the error, formatted according to [JSONpath](https://github.com/json-path/JsonPath).

errorCodeText.description: A standard short description corresponding to the `errorCode`.

errorCodeMessage.description: A long description corresponding to the `errorCode` with additional information.
errorCodeMessage.example: Spaces not allowed in facility code

DetailedError.description: A detailed description of what has caused the error.

Api-Version-Major.name: API-Version
Api-Version-Major.description: An API-Version header **MAY** be added to the request (optional); if added it **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version. API-Version header **MUST** be aligned with the URI version.

CargoType.name: cargoType
CargoType.x-remark: This is a carrier proprietary parameter, which can only be used when the Carrier-Extensions-Version request header is included
CargoType.description:
The type of cargo to be shipped:
* DRY - Dry cargo
* REEF - Reefer (refrigerated) cargo

ISOEquipmentCode.name: ISOEquipmentCode
ISOEquipmentCode.x-remark: This is a carrier proprietary parameter, which can only be used when the Carrier-Extensions-Version request header is included
ISOEquipmentCode.description:
The container size and type BIC code as defined in the ISO-6346 standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO)

<https://www.bic-code.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/SizeAndType-Table1-3.pdf>

StuffingWeight.name: stuffingWeight
StuffingWeight.x-remark: This is a carrier proprietary parameter, which can only be used when the Carrier-Extensions-Version request header is included
StuffingWeight.description: The value for the Gross Weight of the cargo in container, the measurement Unit is KGS

StuffingVolume.name: stuffingVolume
StuffingVolume.x-remark: This is a carrier proprietary parameter, which can only be used when the Carrier-Extensions-Version request header is included
StuffingVolume.description: The value for the Volume of the cargo in container, the measurement Unit is MTQ ( Cubic Meters )

Carrier-Extensions-Version.name: Carrier-Extensions-Version
Carrier-Extensions-Version.description: A Carrier Extensions Version header to indicate the Extensions version. This parameter is mandatory if the consumer wants to use the carrierProprietaryAttributes.  It **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version.

Carrier-Extensions-Version-Header.description: A Carrier Extensions Version header to indicate the Extensions version. This parameter is mandatory if the consumer wants to use the carrierProprietaryAttributes.  It **MUST** only contain **MAJOR** version.

ApiKeyHeader.description: API key used for authorisation to the API
ApiKeyHeader.name: Consumer-Key
